title: The Key-Value Kingdom
story: Dictionaries have powerful methods for working with their keys and values! You can get all keys, all values, check if a key exists, and safely access values with defaults. Master these to become a dictionary wizard!
instructions: Create a dictionary `scores` with 'math': 95, 'science': 88, 'english': 92. Use keys() to get all keys, values() to get all values, and get() to safely get 'history' (which doesn't exist) with default 0. Print keys list, values list, and history score.
solutionHidden:
scores = {"math": 95, "science": 88, "english": 92}
keys_list = list(scores.keys())
values_list = list(scores.values())
history_score = scores.get("history", 0)
print(keys_list)
print(values_list)
print(history_score)

tests.description: Should print keys, values, and history score
tests.expectedBehavior: Output should show all three lists/values

hints.text: Use dict.keys() for keys, dict.values() for values. Convert to list with list()
dict.get(key, default) returns the value if key exists, otherwise returns default
keys_list = list(scores.keys()), values_list = list(scores.values()), history_score = scores.get("history", 0)
